messages.text: It comes down to the fact that Regex engines are very much optimized for finding matches, whereas your `count_pattern` is much slower at finding even the first match. You compare each slice to the full pattern, but Regex engines won't even look at the second character of the pattern if the first one doesn't match (if it's a simple pattern... they can become much more complicated)

elements.text: It comes down to the fact that Regex engines are very much optimized for finding matches, whereas your
count_pattern

is much slower at finding even the first match. You compare each slice to the full pattern, but Regex engines won't even look at the second character of the pattern if the first one doesn't match (if it's a simple pattern... they can become much more complicated)

messages.text:
This version of counting becomes faster than regex
```function count_pattern(text, pattern)
    return length([i for i in Base.findnext(pattern,text,1)])
end```
But why?

elements.text: This version of counting becomes faster than regex
But why?

messages.text:
Hey, shouldn't setting up regex engine take more time than counting with a loop?
```function count_pattern(text, pattern)
    pattern_length = length(pattern)
    let count = 0
        for i in 1:(length(text)-pattern_length+1)
            if text[i:(i+pattern_length-1)] == pattern
                count += 1
            end
        end
    return count
    end
end

function regex_count_pattern(text, pattern)
    return length([i for i in findall(Regex(pattern),text)])
end```
In my cases later regex_count_pattern is faster. Even if I want to search for different patterns it's still way faster. Why would extra overhead related to setting up regex result in a faster code? Is that generally true in any language ?

elements.text: Hey, shouldn't setting up regex engine take more time than counting with a loop?

function count_pattern(text, pattern)
    pattern_length = length(pattern)
    let count = 0
        for i in 1:(length(text)-pattern_length+1)
            if text[i:(i+pattern_length-1)] == pattern
                count += 1
            end
        end
    return count
    end
end

function regex_count_pattern(text, pattern)
    return length([i for i in findall(Regex(pattern),text)])
end

In my cases later regex_count_pattern is faster. Even if I want to search for different patterns it's still way faster. Why would extra overhead related to setting up regex result in a faster code? Is that generally true in any language ?

           @time 1

       end

Hi all,

I need to solve an ordinary differential equation that has a Dirac delta function in it. What is a good way to solve this numerically? I was thinking of approximating the Delta function as a normalized Gaussian. Is that how one is supposed to be solving it?

Something like this:

dy_i/dx = -y_i + \sum_j \delta(y_j -A).

A is a constant and y_i(x=0)  = 0.

Thanks

Lets say you have a script like this
```using ArgParse

s = ArgParseSettings()

@add_arg_table s begin
    "arg1"
    arg_type = Int
	help = "Arg1"
	required = true
end

parsed_args = parse_args(s)
x = parsed_args["arg1"]
print(sum([x, x]))```
Doing `julia myscript.jl 3` takes 3 seconds to execute on my computer everytime.

Whats the best way to precompile this script so that
1. It runs close to instantly upon execution from the command line
2. There are no required intermediate files that are 100MBs in size
3. The goal is to ultimately put a script like this in a docker image, so hopefully it follows the best practices associated with precompilation and docker (a bit vague i know)

messages.text:
As an exercise, I implemented my own unoptimized version of an InsertionSort algorithm. I was rather surprised at the fact that my implementation of the algorithm outperformed Julia's implementation at an array of size < 10 for the most part. Here is Base's implementation:

```function sort!(v::AbstractVector, lo::Integer, hi::Integer, ::InsertionSortAlg, o::Ordering)
    @inbounds for i = lo+1:hi
        j = i
        x = v[i]
        while j > lo
            if lt(o, x, v[j-1])
                v[j] = v[j-1]
                j -= 1
                continue
            end
            break
        end
        v[j] = x
    end
    return v
end```
Here is my implementation:

```function insertionsort(input)

    @inbounds for curr = 2:length(input)
        prior = curr - 1
        while prior != 0
            if input[curr] < input[prior]
                input[curr], input[prior] = input[prior], input[curr]
            end
            curr = prior
            prior -= 1
        end
    end
    return input
end```
However, this performance advantage was quickly outpaced by Julia's implementation and I was curious if anyone could explain a few things related to Julia's implementation:

1. What is the `@inbounds` macro and why is it suggested to be used? It seems redundant and it negatively impacted my time when I tried to use it.
2. When is it wise to make the trade off between allocations and speed? My implementation only made 1 and is always around half the allocation size of Base's.
3. As this is an exercise, what should I consider more in the future to improve my algorithms?
Thanks everyone for the help! Much appreciated! :smile:

P.S. Here is how I ran benchmarks on my code (thanks to <@U6N6VQE30> for some feedback on benchmarking!):

```using BenchmarkTools

input = rand(100)

@btime(insertionsort($input)) |> println
@btime(sort!($input, alg=InsertionSort)) |> println```
Which produces:

```  2.845 μs (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
  208.888 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes))```

elements.text: As an exercise, I implemented my own unoptimized version of an InsertionSort algorithm. I was rather surprised at the fact that my implementation of the algorithm outperformed Julia's implementation at an array of size < 10 for the most part. Here is Base's implementation:

function sort!(v::AbstractVector, lo::Integer, hi::Integer, ::InsertionSortAlg, o::Ordering)
    @inbounds for i = lo+1:hi
        j = i
        x = v[i]
        while j > lo
            if lt(o, x, v[j-1])
                v[j] = v[j-1]
                j -= 1
                continue
            end
            break
        end
        v[j] = x
    end
    return v
end
Here is my implementation:

function insertionsort(input)

    @inbounds for curr = 2:length(input)
        prior = curr - 1
        while prior != 0
            if input[curr] < input[prior]
                input[curr], input[prior] = input[prior], input[curr]
            end
            curr = prior
            prior -= 1
        end
    end
    return input
end
However, this performance advantage was quickly outpaced by Julia's implementation and I was curious if anyone could explain a few things related to Julia's implementation:
What is the
@inbounds
macro and why is it suggested to be used? It seems redundant and it negatively impacted my time when I tried to use it.
When is it wise to make the trade off between allocations and speed? My implementation only made 1 and is always around half the allocation size of Base's.
As this is an exercise, what should I consider more in the future to improve my algorithms?
Thanks everyone for the help! Much appreciated!
P.S. Here is how I ran benchmarks on my code (thanks to
for some feedback on benchmarking!):
Which produces:

2.845 μs (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
  208.888 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes))

I would like a quick confirmation. I think I am looping in the wrong way for speed. Indeed, in the following code, F is likely to loop over the indices of `xc[:, i]`
```xc = reshape(x, N, M) # size(x) = (N*M,)
dxc = similar(xc)
for i=1:M
    dxc[:, i] .= F(xc[:, i])
end
   ```

messages.text:
Is it possible to apply `using` at runtime? This doesn't seem to be it:
```julia> macroexpand(Main, :(using $pkg))
:($(Expr(:using, :($(Expr(:., "BenchmarkTools"))))))```
The simplest solution I could find was:
```julia> macroexpand(Main, Meta.parse("using $pkg"))
:(using BenchmarkTools)```
But I wonder how to do it with macros.

messages.text:
is there a standard way to propagate the view macro/command?
for example, I have a function that returns a slice of a parent array, but a user may want that slice to be a view. for example-
```data = randn(512, 512)
myview = MyView(data; options...)
# gets a subset of the data
sub = myview(1)
# gets a subset of the data as a view
sub = @view myview(1)```
internally the function i’m calling looks like this-
```function (v::MyView)(idx::Int)
    idxs = v.filtered_idxs[idx]
    return v.parent[idxs]
end```

elements.text:

for example, I have a function that returns a slice of a parent array, but a user may want that slice to be a view. for example-

myview = MyView(data; options...)
# gets a subset of the data
sub = myview(1)
# gets a subset of the data as a view
sub = @view myview(1)
internally the function i’m calling looks like this-

function (v::MyView)(idx::Int)
    idxs = v.filtered_idxs[idx]
    return v.parent[idxs]
end

messages.text:
Some thread-safety help please: I have the following function

```function myfun(x_vec::Vector{MyType}, δ::Matrix{Float64}, buffer)

    ∑x = 0.0

    Threads.@threads for i ∈ 1:length(x_vec)
        ∑x += sum(my_other_fun(x_vec[i], δ[i, :])[3])
    end

    return ∑x
end```
which works fine unthreaded but comes out incorrectly when I add `@threads`. Any ideas what might throw it off without seeing `my_other_fun`?

messages.text:
does anybody know why performance for broadcasting getindex is an order of magnitude slower than first?
```julia> typeof(data)
Array{Tuple{Int64,String},1}

julia> length(data)
1000

julia> @benchmark first.(data)
BenchmarkTools.Trial:
  memory estimate:  8.00 KiB
  allocs estimate:  4
  --------------
  minimum time:     880.952 ns (0.00% GC)
  median time:      1.205 μs (0.00% GC)
  mean time:        1.336 μs (9.94% GC)
  maximum time:     47.986 μs (93.33% GC)
  --------------
  samples:          10000
  evals/sample:     21

julia> @benchmark getindex.(data,1)
BenchmarkTools.Trial:
  memory estimate:  39.36 KiB
  allocs estimate:  1006
  --------------
  minimum time:     17.299 μs (0.00% GC)
  median time:      18.000 μs (0.00% GC)
  mean time:        19.646 μs (3.50% GC)
  maximum time:     1.082 ms (97.40% GC)
  --------------
  samples:          10000
  evals/sample:     1```

messages.text:
kind of a weird issue I ran into today, I had a dangling 'where' that didn't refer to anything but it surprisingly affects the code the compiler generates
```using BenchmarkTools

function foo(x) where BlahBlah
    return x+1
end

function bar(x)
    return x+1
end

let
    @btime foo(127)
    @btime bar(127)
end```
gives
```  10.891 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
  0.020 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)```

elements.text: kind of a weird issue I ran into today, I had a dangling 'where' that didn't refer to anything but it surprisingly affects the code the compiler generates

using BenchmarkTools

function foo(x) where BlahBlah
    return x+1
end

function bar(x)
    return x+1
end

let
    @btime foo(127)
    @btime bar(127)
end
gives

10.891 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
  0.020 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)

messages.text:
Hi,

I would like to warp an image by the log-polar transform but I have troubles to make it work. Can someone give me a push please?

```using CoordinateTransformations, ImageTransformations, StaticArrays
struct Retinotopy <: Transformation; end
struct InvRetinotopy <: Transformation; end
function (::Retinotopy)(x)
    length(x) == 2 || error("Polar transform takes a 2D coordinate")

    Polar(log(hypot(x[1], x[2])), atan(x[2], x[1]))
end

function (::InvRetinotopy)(x::Polar)
    s,c = sincos(x.θ)
    SVector(exp(x.r) * c, exp(x.r) * s)
end
(t::InvRetinotopy)(x) = t(Polar(x[1], x[2]))
Base.inv(::Retinotopy) = InvRetinotopy()

tfm = Retinotopy()
# image
img = rand(256, 256)
imgw = warp(img, tfm);```

elements.text:
Hi,

I would like to warp an image by the log-polar transform but I have troubles to make it work. Can someone give me a push please?

using CoordinateTransformations, ImageTransformations, StaticArrays
struct Retinotopy <: Transformation; end
struct InvRetinotopy <: Transformation; end
function (::Retinotopy)(x)
    length(x) == 2 || error("Polar transform takes a 2D coordinate")

    Polar(log(hypot(x[1], x[2])), atan(x[2], x[1]))
end

function (::InvRetinotopy)(x::Polar)
    s,c = sincos(x.θ)
    SVector(exp(x.r) * c, exp(x.r) * s)
end
(t::InvRetinotopy)(x) = t(Polar(x[1], x[2]))
Base.inv(::Retinotopy) = InvRetinotopy()

tfm = Retinotopy()
# image
img = rand(256, 256)
imgw = warp(img, tfm);
